title: Writing Claim and Exposure Validation Rules
sourceFile: 06 - Writing Claim and Exposure Validation Rules.pptx
sourceFolder: 06 - Writing Claim and Exposure Validation Rules

slides.title: Writing Claim and Exposure Validation Rules
slides.originalNotes:
How ClaimCenter validates data
There are two totally different kinds of data validation in ClaimCenter.
The first is validation of particular fields. This ensures, for example, that a US ZIP (postal) code has exactly 5 or exactly 9 digits; anything else is malformed and must be rejected (not saved). Similarly, the date and time of loss for a claim must not be prior to today's date.

The second type of validation is validation by rules. This is related to the object maturity model, which we will cover in a few slides. The point here is that rules can prevent a claim from moving Zbackwards" by removal of or changes to data already present, and can prevent a new claim from being saved at all if it doesn't meet certain standards.
slides.notes:

The second type of validation is validation by rules. This is related to the object maturity model, which we will cover in a few slides. The point here is that rules can prevent a claim from moving Zbackwards" by removal of or changes to data already present, and can prevent a new claim from being saved at all if it doesn't meet certain standards.

* Two ways:
• Validation by field ensures that data is of valid type, range, and so on
* Validation by rules manages and enforces object maturity

• Both occur when an object is updated

slides.title: Validation by fields
slides.originalNotes:
Validation by fields
Validation by fields is the simpler of the two types of data validation provided by ClaimCenter. On any given field displayed in the I-II, you can provide an optional validation expression.

If the validation expression evaluates to null, the input is accepted; if it does not, the field throws a validation error as shown in the upper screenshot. The validation expression can be arbitrarily complex, and it can reference other fields (whether those other fields are visible in the IJI or not).
slides.notes:
Validation by fields
Validation by fields is the simpler of the two types of data validation provided by ClaimCenter. On any given field displayed in the I-II, you can provide an optional validation expression.

If the validation expression evaluates to null, the input is accepted; if it does not, the field throws a validation error as shown in the upper screenshot. The validation expression can be arbitrarily complex, and it can reference other fields (whether those other fields are visible in the IJI or not).
slides.ocrText:
| Validation by fields G

• Widgets enforce data type
• Validation expressions ensure that data is of correct format, range, and so on

slides.title: Validation rule sets
slides.originalNotes:
What can be validated
Refresher: A delegate is an entity type that contains methods and properties which can be used by other entity types.

Validatable provides the various reject() methods we will discuss later.

The list on the right shows the validation rule sets provided in the base product for Validatable entities. Though there are many Validatable entities in the ClaimCenter base configuration, there are not quite as many as the list on the right would seem to imply. For example, ClaimClosedValidationRules,“ Zclaim ReopenedValidationRules,“ and CliamValidationRules" all have the same base entity, the claim.

slides.title: Validation by rules
slides.originalNotes:
Validation by rules
Validation by rules is based on the maturity level, or validation level, of an entity such as a Claim or an Exposure, and helps to prevent an entity from going backwards in its lifecycle.

For example, if a claim is ready to be paid, and a user changes data that would invalidate the ability to pay the claim, then the system will display an error message, and will not allow the entity to be saved.

Validation rules also enable more complex validations than can be easily fit into a validationExpression property. In the example shown in the screenshots, the rule checks the total of the liability percentages for all responsible parties on a subrogation. If that adds up to a liability greater than one hundred percent, then ClaimCenter validation rules will prevent the claim with the subrogation attached to it from being saved until the error is corrected.
slides.notes:
Validation by rules
Validation by rules is based on the maturity level, or validation level, of an entity such as a Claim or an Exposure, and helps to prevent an entity from going backwards in its lifecycle.

For example, if a claim is ready to be paid, and a user changes data that would invalidate the ability to pay the claim, then the system will display an error message, and will not allow the entity to be saved.

Validation rules also enable more complex validations than can be easily fit into a validationExpression property. In the example shown in the screenshots, the rule checks the total of the liability percentages for all responsible parties on a subrogation. If that adds up to a liability greater than one hundred percent, then ClaimCenter validation rules will prevent the claim with the subrogation attached to it from being saved until the error is corrected.
slides.ocrText:
| Validation by rules Gi

• Rules prevent values from being saved which are inappropriate to the entity's
current maturity level

• Use “reject” methods to provide warning and error messages to the user

« Warning and error messages appear in a Validation Results worksheet in the lower part of the
screen

slides.title: ValidationLevel
slides.originalNotes:
Validation Level
Validation levels identify the maturity level of a claim or exposure.

They are ordered by the value their Priority. The higher the priority, the earlier it appears ir the sequence. Thus, "load ant save" is the lowest maturity lei, and Ability to pay" is the highf As the entity goes through its I cycle, it advances through the: maturity/validation levels until reaches "Ability to pay".
slides.notes:
Validation Level
Validation levels identify the maturity level of a claim or exposure.

They are ordered by the value their Priority. The higher the priority, the earlier it appears ir the sequence. Thus, "load ant save" is the lowest maturity lei, and Ability to pay" is the highf As the entity goes through its I cycle, it advances through the: maturity/validation levels until reaches "Ability to pay".
slides.ocrText:
| ValidationLevel

• Typelist that provides a set of maturity levels for claims and exposures

* The base configuration provides five validation levels

• In order, they are:

loadsave — entity loaded from an external
FNOL system*

newloss — entity newly entered by an agent*

iso — entity ready to send to ISO (the Insurance
Services Office) (fraud prevention)

external — entity ready to send to external
systems

payment — entity is ready for payment to
claimants*

* These three validation levels are “final” and cannot be edited or deleted.

slides.title: How ClaimCenter uses validation levels
slides.originalNotes:
How ClaimCenter uses validation levels
Every entity that implements Validatable has a reference, real or implied, to the Validation Level typelist (implied references are to the virtual property ValidationResult). The purpose of this column is to provide the current maturity level of the entity The system prevents validatable entities from going "backwards" in the maturity levels.

Thus, an entity which has reached the point where it can be sent to external systems can not return to validation iso, newloss, or loadsave. And any data which is required or constrained at the current level cannot be deleted or changed so as not to meet the constraints of the current level.
slides.notes:
How ClaimCenter uses validation levels
Every entity that implements Validatable has a reference, real or implied, to the Validation Level typelist (implied references are to the virtual property ValidationResult). The purpose of this column is to provide the current maturity level of the entity The system prevents validatable entities from going "backwards" in the maturity levels.

Thus, an entity which has reached the point where it can be sent to external systems can not return to validation iso, newloss, or loadsave. And any data which is required or constrained at the current level cannot be deleted or changed so as not to meet the constraints of the current level.
slides.ocrText:
| How ClaimCenter uses validation levels Gi

Validatable entities have an actual or implied ValidationLevel

Entities are validated whenever a user or process attempts to save them
* Validates minimum data completeness and correctness at each maturity level
« Ensures that entities do not move “backwards” through the process

Entities are promoted through the Validation Levels

Prevents save if changes do not meet standards for the current level of validation

slides.title: Validation can prevent saving
slides.originalNotes:
Validation can prevent saving
Validation, as mentioned before, prevents entities from moving backwards in the maturation process. Thus, if data changes would result in no longer meeting the criteria, ClaimCenter will not allow those data changes to be saved.

In the scenario on the slide, the validation rules to reach Level 3 require that the County field be populated. In the first example, county is present, so the validation level is 3. Then in the second example, a user deletes the county informatiom When the user tries to save, ClaimCenter does not permit it, because the claim is at Level 3. The claim cannot move back to Level 2.
slides.notes:
Validation can prevent saving
Validation, as mentioned before, prevents entities from moving backwards in the maturation process. Thus, if data changes would result in no longer meeting the criteria, ClaimCenter will not allow those data changes to be saved.

In the scenario on the slide, the validation rules to reach Level 3 require that the County field be populated. In the first example, county is present, so the validation level is 3. Then in the second example, a user deletes the county informatiom When the user tries to save, ClaimCenter does not permit it, because the claim is at Level 3. The claim cannot move back to Level 2.

slides.title: Entities are promoted to the highest possible maturity level
slides.originalNotes:
Entities are promoted to the highest possible maturity level
Whenever a Validatable entity is saved, validation rules are run against it This results in each entity immediately reaching the highest level of maturity possible for its current state.

In the scenario, Level 3 requires that the County field be populated, and Level 4 requires that an inspection has been done. In the first example, the inspection has been done, but the County field is not populated, so the claim remains at Level 2.

In the second example, the user has populated the County field. This would normally result in promotion to Level 3. But, because the inspection is already done, the claim skips past Level 3 to Level 4.
slides.notes:
Entities are promoted to the highest possible maturity level
Whenever a Validatable entity is saved, validation rules are run against it This results in each entity immediately reaching the highest level of maturity possible for its current state.

In the scenario, Level 3 requires that the County field be populated, and Level 4 requires that an inspection has been done. In the first example, the inspection has been done, but the County field is not populated, so the claim remains at Level 2.

In the second example, the user has populated the County field. This would normally result in promotion to Level 3. But, because the inspection is already done, the claim skips past Level 3 to Level 4.

slides.title: Related objects can trigger validation
slides.originalNotes:
Related objects can trigger validation
When you update an activity, if it is related to a claim or an exposure, that claim or exposure is also updated, because of the foreign key relationship.

For example, the Activities array on the Claim entity has the triggersValidation property set to true, so when you add or update an activity, the claim which the activity is associated with also updates.

Updates can cascade. For example, updating an activity associated with an exposure triggers an update of the exposure. Then the update of the exposure also triggers an update of its parent claim.

Most arrays with triggersValidation set to true are linked to the Claim and Exposure entities, but there are a few others scattered around the application as well.
slides.notes:
Related objects can trigger validation
When you update an activity, if it is related to a claim or an exposure, that claim or exposure is also updated, because of the foreign key relationship.

For example, the Activities array on the Claim entity has the triggersValidation property set to true, so when you add or update an activity, the claim which the activity is associated with also updates.

Updates can cascade. For example, updating an activity associated with an exposure triggers an update of the exposure. Then the update of the exposure also triggers an update of its parent claim.

Most arrays with triggersValidation set to true are linked to the Claim and Exposure entities, but there are a few others scattered around the application as well.
slides.ocrText:
| Related objects can trigger validation Gi

• Updating some objects with a foreign key (child) relationship to a Validatable
object can cause the object to be validated

* Caused by a property, triggersValidation, on the array that implements the parent relationship

slides.title: Errors and warnings
slides.originalNotes:
Errors and warnings
Validation rules can produce errors or warnings about a field that does not validate properly. In the slide, there are examples of both — a warning about excess expected recovery, and an error about the total percentage of liability for •adverse" parties to subrogation. The warning will not keep you from saving the claim, but the error will.

You can have both a warning and an error on the same field. For example, an adjuster could create an Auto claim with a vehicle damage exposure and leave the description field on the vehicle incident blank. An exposure validation rule could be written that displays a warning message for the empty description at the newloss level, and an error message at the ISO level to prevent the exposure from being sent to ISO until the description is added. Both of these conditions can be tested in a single rule, although that is not the case on this slide.
slides.notes:
Errors and warnings
Validation rules can produce errors or warnings about a field that does not validate properly. In the slide, there are examples of both — a warning about excess expected recovery, and an error about the total percentage of liability for •adverse" parties to subrogation. The warning will not keep you from saving the claim, but the error will.

You can have both a warning and an error on the same field. For example, an adjuster could create an Auto claim with a vehicle damage exposure and leave the description field on the vehicle incident blank. An exposure validation rule could be written that displays a warning message for the empty description at the newloss level, and an error message at the ISO level to prevent the exposure from being sent to ISO until the description is added. Both of these conditions can be tested in a single rule, although that is not the case on this slide.
slides.ocrText:
| Errors and warnings Gi

• Errors prevent an object from being promoted to and saved at a given level, and
display an explanatory message

• Warnings permit promotion and saving, but display a cautionary message

slides.title: Configuring validation
slides.ocrText: Configuring validation

slides.title: entity.reject() methods
slides.originalNotes:
entity.reject() methods
There are several reject() methods provided with the Validatable delegate.

All reject() methods offer the choice of issuing an error, a warning, or both. In both cases, you populate two parameters: the maturity level at which the validation takes place, and the message to be displayed when the validation fails.

If the rule is to issue both a warning and an error, the error should be issued at a higher level of maturity than the warning. Othewise, if the error is issued, the warning will never be processed. (This is why the error parameters come before the warning parameters in the method signature.)
slides.notes:
entity.reject() methods
There are several reject() methods provided with the Validatable delegate.

All reject() methods offer the choice of issuing an error, a warning, or both. In both cases, you populate two parameters: the maturity level at which the validation takes place, and the message to be displayed when the validation fails.

If the rule is to issue both a warning and an error, the error should be issued at a higher level of maturity than the warning. Othewise, if the error is issued, the warning will never be processed. (This is why the error parameters come before the warning parameters in the method signature.)
slides.ocrText:
entity.reject() methods Ga

Can be used for both warnings and errors.

slides.title: entity.reject() method
slides.ocrText:
| entity.reject() method

* Syntax:
entity.reject(errorLevel, errorMessage,
warnLevel, warnMessage)
* Parameters:
* errorLevel = validation level to display an error message
* errorMessage = error message to display
* warnLevel = validation level to display a warning message

* warnMessage = warning message to display

+ Either errorLevel and errorMessage, or warnLevel and warnMessage, must be
non-null

* Both pairs can be non-null

* errorLevel should be a higher maturity level than warnLevel

slides.title: entity.rejectField() method
slides.ocrText:
| entity.rejectField() method G

* Indicates a problem with a particular field, displays a warning or error message and highlights
the field in the UI

* Syntax:

entity.rejectField(strRelativeFieldPath,
errorLevel, errorMessage,

warnLevel, warnMessage)
New Parameter:
e strRelativeFieldPath = the path from the root object of this rule to the field failing validation

claim. rejectField("FaultRating",TC_NEWLOSS,
"{ruleName}\: The Fault Rating must be determin...", null, null)

slides.title: entity.rejectSubField() method
slides.ocrText:
| entity.rejectSubField() method Ga

• Highlights fields on related objects (such as those on an array or a foreign key)
« May require navigation to a page for the related object field (which will be highlighted)
• If so, a link will be available in the Validation Results worksheet

• Syntax:

entity.rejectSubField(relatedObject, strRelativeFieldPath,
errorLevel, errorMessage,

warnLevel, warnMessage)
« New Parameter:
• relatedObject — the sub-object on which the reject field is found

claim.rejectSubField(exp, "OtherCoverageDet",
TC_NEWLOSS, "Please provide information about claimant's ot...",
null, null)

slides.title: Validation rules
slides.ocrText:
Validation rules

Most of the logic is usually in the condition clause

* Selects entities that should be rejected

• You can put additional logic into the action clause

USES:
uses gw.api.locale.DisplayKey
CONDITION (claim : entity.Claim):

return claim.Evaluations.where(\evaluation -> evaluation.isChanged()).hasMatch
(\evaluation -> {

var liabilities = {evaluation.InsuredLiability, evaluation.ClaimantLiability,
evaluation. OtherLiability}
return liabilities.where(\liability -> liability != null).sum() > 100
»
ACTION (claim : entity.Claim, actions : gw.rules.Action) :

claim. reject (claim.ValidationLevel, "Total liability percentage of evaluation canno...

, null, null)
END
